author: Grimms
text: There was once upon a time a poor peasant called Crabb, who drove with two oxen a load of wood to the town, and sold it to a doctor for two talers.

author: Grimms
text: When the money was being counted out to him, it so happened that the doctor was sitting at table, and when the peasant saw how well he ate and drank, his heart desired what he saw, and would willingly have been a doctor too.

author: Grimms
text: So he remained standing a while, and at length inquired if he too could not be a doctor.

author: Grimms
text: "Oh, yes," said the doctor, "that is soon managed."

author: Grimms
text: "What must I do?" asked the peasant.

author: Grimms
text: "In the first place buy yourself an A B C book of the kind which has a cock on the frontispiece; in the second, turn your cart and your two oxen into money, and get yourself some clothes, and whatsoever else pertains to medicine; thirdly, have a sign painted for yourself with the words: "I am Doctor Knowall," and have that nailed up above your house-door."

author: Grimms
text: The peasant did everything that he had been told to do.

author: Grimms
text: When he had doctored people awhile, but not long, a rich and great lord had some money stolen.

author: Grimms
text: Then he was told about Doctor Knowall who lived in such and such a village, and must know what had become of the money.

author: Grimms
text: So the lord had the horses harnessed to his carriage, drove out to the village, and asked Crabb if he were Doctor Knowall.

author: Grimms
text: Yes, he was, he said.

author: Grimms
text: Then he was to go with him and bring back the stolen money.

author: Grimms
text: "Oh, yes, but Grete, my wife, must go too."

author: Grimms
text: The lord was willing, and let both of them have a seat in the carriage, and they all drove away together.

author: Grimms
text: When they came to the nobleman"s castle, the table was spread, and Crabb was told to sit down and eat.

author: Grimms
text: "Yes, but my wife, Grete, too," said he, and he seated himself with her at the table.

author: Grimms
text: And when the first servant came with a dish of delicate fare, the peasant nudged his wife, and said: "Grete, that was the first," meaning that was the servant who brought the first dish.

author: Grimms
text: The servant, however, thought he intended by that to say: "That is the first thief," and as he actually was so, he was terrified, and said to his comrade outside: "The doctor knows all: we shall fare ill, he said I was the first."

author: Grimms
text: The second did not want to go in at all, but was forced.

author: Grimms
text: So when he went in with his dish, the peasant nudged his wife, and said: "Grete, that is the second."

author: Grimms
text: This servant was equally alarmed, and he got out as fast as he could.

author: Grimms
text: The third fared no better, for the peasant again said: "Grete, that is the third."

author: Grimms
text: The fourth had to carry in a dish that was covered, and the lord told the doctor that he was to show his skill, and guess what was beneath the cover.

author: Grimms
text: Actually, there were crabs.

author: Grimms
text: The doctor looked at the dish, had no idea what to say, and cried: "Ah, poor Crabb."

author: Grimms
text: When the lord heard that, he cried: "There! he knows it; he must also know who has the money!"

author: Grimms
text: On this the servants looked terribly uneasy, and made a sign to the doctor that they wished him to step outside for a moment.

author: Grimms
text: When therefore he went out, all four of them confessed to him that they had stolen the money, and said that they would willingly restore it and give him a heavy sum into the bargain, if he would not denounce them, for if he did they would be hanged.

author: Grimms
text: They led him to the spot where the money was concealed.

author: Grimms
text: With this the doctor was satisfied, and returned to the hall, sat down to the table, and said: "My lord, now will I search in my book where the gold is hidden."

author: Grimms
text: The fifth servant, however, crept into the stove to hear if the doctor knew still more.

author: Grimms
text: But the doctor sat still and opened his A B C book, turned the pages backwards and forwards, and looked for the cock.

author: Grimms
text: As he could not find it immediately he said: "I know you are there, so you had better come out!"

author: Grimms
text: Then the fellow in the stove thought that the doctor meant him, and full of terror, sprang out, crying: "That man knows everything!"

author: Grimms
text: Then Doctor Knowall showed the lord where the money was, but did not say who had stolen it, and received from both sides much money in reward, and became a renowned man.
